item.title: Origin and Integration, a new report using Census 2016 data
item.description: We have a new report! We recently launched Origin and Integration, a piece of work that looks at migrant integration in Ireland. Here, we look at education, english language ability, unemployment and occupational attianment for migrants from over 100+ countries of birth. It’s a really exciting project, one that uses the entire migrant population in Ireland. You can read it here!

item.title: Working with ESS data in R
item.description: I came across a good step by step guide for using European Social Survey in R. I had some issues with the code, and in the end I found that tidyverse has some nice alternatives to the code preseneted, like the stuff on weighting, but in general this was a really interesting post. I want to walk through some of my workflow here. We can start by loading some of the ESS data for the Russian Federation.

item.title: A Note of Appreciation for case_when
item.description: I wanted to make a quick post about the dplyr:: function, case_when(). More for my own sanity than for public outreach. In Stata, recoding variables is relatively straight forward, at least to me. However, I’ve recently tried to use recode() in dplyr:: and could not get my head around it. Someone on stackoverflow suggested using case_when() which is somewhat understandable. Here’s an example. library(tidyverse) ## -- Attaching packages ------------------- tidyverse 1.

item.title: Visualising job changes using ggplot
item.description: I started working on a new paper, one that looks at job mobility in the RLMS data-set. In general, I’m really interested in the effects of job changes on wages, but often reviewers ask about predicting mobility and the factors that correlate with mobility, so in this paper I’m trying to look at both of these things, which can get a bit convoluted. Anyway, in this blog post I list a few visualisations from this paper which I’m including instead of tables.

item.title: New Papers
item.description: I wanted to include a small update on two recent publications. I know the blog is a bit neglected this is because I’ve started a postdoc and my first few reports are coming out. The first is about unpaid work in Ireland and its gender differences. I just caught the tail end of the work as I started, but I’m glad I had an input. Generally we find high levels of unpaid work in Ireland when compared to other countries in Europe.

item.title: Job mobility with promotions
item.description: I’ve been thinking a lot about capturing internal and external mobility types in the RLMS. I previously wrote a small note on one measure in the RLMS. That particular post was kind of disappointing, the data suggested that mobility was extremely uncommon, and although Russia is a famously immobile labour market, where respondents stay in the same job even when employers decide to stop paying wages, it seems like this question may be skewed somehow.

item.title: Poverty, shoes, and Rosstat
item.description: Rosstat, Russia’s main authority on state figures, recently released a summary of poverty and deprivation. One of the main findings suggests that 33% of households cannot afford two pairs of seasonally appropriate shoes for everyone in the home. A few publications picked up on the finding, and the Kremlin supposedly rejects the body’s figures.. Generally, Russia’s wages are famously low the median hourly wage works out at roughly 0.91 net per hour in British pounds.

item.title: Marriage status and earnings
item.description: A common explanation for inequality among conservative types stresses the importance of marriage. The logic boils down to two basic points, one directly influential and one less directly influential. The first point claims married couples are more productive. Even those dependent on a single paycheck work together towards a common goal. Here, a wife looks after the home and children, while the husband earns a paycheck. Since they both focus on the long term development of the home they’re able to enssure that the primary earner, usually the man, is best place to secure higher earnings.

item.title: Migration
item.description: In this post I look at migration figures released by Rosstat. A number of debates are happening in Russia about the inflow and outflow of migrants from former Soviet countries, and the effect these migrants have on wages. Separately, there is an argument that migration from Ukraine is falling, which likely has its own challenges. What do these inflows look like? Rosstat releases data on this, but it’s awkward for three reasons.

item.title: Russian Opinion of Ukraine and Ukrainian Opinion of Russia
item.description: Levada recently updated statistics on what Russian and Ukrainian citizens think of each other. I saw the update but forgot to dig into the numbers; yesterday’s events in Kerch reminded me to revisit these. It seems like conflict between both countries is on the rise, but it’s worth looking back on how public opinion changed over the quieter months. In this post I merge the data gathered by Levada, and use some dplyr commands to simplify things, I then make a graph using ggplot.

item.title: Job Mobility in Russia
item.description: This post explores job mobility data in the Russian labour market. Sociologists tend to see country differences in job mobility as stemming from country differences in institutions. I think these can be summarised into three cateogries. First, there are differences in job protection and the freedom to fire or hire workers. Liberal countries, like the UK, have more mobility because hiring and firing workers is just easier. By the same token, coordinated economies like Germany, tend to have less mobility because firing workers, and the process of hiring, takes longer and contains more obstacles.

item.title: Visualising LME output
item.description: In this post I want to summarise a quick method for summarising random-effects output. I’ve been working with multi-level models recently. During grad school I spent a lot of time using fixed-effects methods, which are less prone to bias but drop lots of information between cluster groups. Random effects models also have issues, but new methods have made it easier to overcome these. There are tonnes of interesting courses and books on random effects modelling, which are worth reading.

item.title: Xenophobia towards migrants
item.description: In this post I want to look at data on xenophobia and attitudes to migrants; collected by the Levada center. This dataset was recently updated and widely shared, there are some interesting trends in the graphs below, some of which tell conflicting stories about migrants and ethnicities. Mainly, the graphs show an increase in xenophobic attitudes, after a period of falling xenophobia. However, subtle signs of acceptance also emerge, which could indicate a willingness to live and work with migrants once Russians get to know such (hypothetical) people.

item.title: Parents' Expectations 2004-2018
item.description: A recent post from Russia’s Levada Centre caught my attention. On the topic of school and future careers, parents are asked what they would like their children to do, what professions they prefer them to choose. Levada collected this data from 2004, so it’s possible to track parents’ expectations of their kids over time (somewhat). The format is not ideal, occuaptions seem to be in broad categories, not all of which are related.

item.title: Adding Observations in RLMS using R
item.description: In this update, I want to update the blog with a practical post. I’ll try to group observations in the Russian Longitudinal Monitoring Survey by individual. In a nutshell, every year, the survey asks people a series of questions, but some respondents are revisited and asked the same questions at another point in time. This is the basis for longitudinal data. I should add a disclaimer, I have a limited knowledge of the Russia Longitudinal Monitoring Survey, and it’s possible that other, better methods exist.

item.title: Vacancy and the CSO
item.description: This post addresses the issue of housing vacancy. The views below are mine alone and represent my opinion and interpretation of the data; other interpretations exist. tl;dr I think housing vacancy is misunderstood, and often over-simplified. The current government is pursuing vacant homes in an effort to increase social housing supply. The strategy is unlikely to yield significant returns in Dublin, since the nature of Dublin’s vacancy may be misunderstood.

item.title: Rising Income, Rising Price
item.description: Rising Income, Rising Price A recent report by myhome.ie (Q4 2017) listed several reasons for the sharp rise in house prices, especially in Dublin. The most noticeable was “rising incomes” and “strong job growth”. This may suggest the following; wages rose significantly in recent years, more disposable income meant more bidding between buyers which pushed the price of housing. I may be nitpicking; the report also lists other good reasons for the growth in price.

item.title: Compensating Differentials and Premiums for "Dangerous Work"
item.description: A key theory predicting differences in pay, and explaining pay inequality, lies in compensating differentials. This is the idea that pay premiums are attached to jobs that have unfavourable or dangerous working conditions. Thus, workers who are at risk earn more than equally skilled workers in safer jobs. The theory often gets cited by critics of the gender pay gap. Here, it is argued that women accept lower pay in trying to “buy” better working conditions (or simply more favourable conditions).

item.title: Public Thoughts on Politics and Government
item.description: The European Social Survey for 2016 lists variables on government and politics. These are worth exploring, especially with the rise of protests and public meetings against the Kremlin. Often, critics claim these are disingenuous movements, made to create media content in Europe and the States. Typically, they point to Putin’s high approval rating as a symbol that all is well, and the population holds pro-government views. In this post I explore some specifics, how do Russians feel about government, their ability to impact policy, and their ability to influence political outcomes?

item.title: Industry Differences in Pay
item.description: In this post I outline industry differences in pay, with a special focus on gender. I already listed the occupational differences in a previous post. Here, I follow the same idea, but substitute industry for occupations. As before, I use the Russian Longitudinal Monitoring Survey for data on participants in 2015. I use a measure for gender, industry, the number of weekly hours worked, and gross wages. I do not limit the industry codes, but focus on industry as it appears in the survey.

item.title: Gender, occupations, and pay
item.description: In this post, I look at a small chart breaking down pay by gender and occupation. Russian wages are particularly flexible, employers have significant freedom in setting the earnings of “inefficient” workers. There’s also a lot of “hidden unemployment”, where workers see their hours deducted at times of low demand (or at the discretion of employers) and where unpaid leave is common. These reasons may contribute to Russia’s gender pay gap.

item.title: About
item.description: I’m a social researcher based in Dublin, Ireland. Here, I write about Russian inequality using cross sectional and longitudinal data. My main interests are the sociology of work, Russia’s place in comparative political economy, its wage inequality, and its social classes at work. I wrote my PhD on the consequences of job mobility in Germany and the UK; from time to time I’ll also blog about that. Separately, I’m trying to learn about R Studio, data viz, and longitudinal or panel methods of analysis.

item.title: Working papers
item.description: This section contains some working papers. Typically these are not reviewed yet but they contain the main ideas or arguments. Job Mobility and Earnings: Comparing Germany and the UK In this paper I’m trying to compare the effects of quitting and the effects of moving due to a promotion in both countries. Germany typically has far less mobility than the UK, does this mean that the UK has more “life chances” than Germany?

item.title: My First Post
item.description: Thanks for visiting my blog. I’m looking forward to writing some posts about Russia, and learning some much needed R skills here. My rationale for starting, was to learn more about R and blogdown. Since you typically need data for both of those things, I decided to focus on something I’m interested in; Russian Society, labour markets, and sociology. If nothing else, this might be a good exercise for learning blocks of code.
